uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io
Class Lexer

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Lexer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Seekable<uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell>
public final class Lexer
extends Object
implements uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Seekable<uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell>, Closeable

A Lexer performs lexical analysis of some delimited input file. It produces lexemes (lexical tokens) that can be interpreted by a parser or handler of some sort.

Written as a replacement for the many other tokenisers available, it offers a unique combination of features:

  • Extremely fast, NIO based, buffered reading.
  • Semi-random access allowing return to any previous lexeme position.
  • No unnecessary object instantiation (e.g. String fragments). This is achieved using lazy iteration with an advance/accessor control. Insures that only the absolute minimum amount of work is done at each step.

Lexer is not thread safe and must be synchronized externally if concurrent access is required.

Requires Java 6

Example Usage:

 File infile = new File("/path/to/data/file");
 FileChannel fc = new FileInputStream(infile).getChannel();
 MappedByteBuffer bbuf = fc.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, fc.size());

 RaspLexer lexer = new RaspLexer(bbuf, Charset.forName("ISO-8859-15"));
 lexer.addDelimiter(')');
 lexer.addDelimiter('(');

 while (lexer.hasNext()) {
     lexer.advance();

     System.out.printf("%-6d %-12s %-6d %-6d %-15s%n",
         lexer.number(),
         lexer.type(),
         lexer.start(), lexer.end(),
         lexer.value());
 }

ToDo

  • Implement configurable lexeme types. Each type should be defined by a name and a character matcher. The character matcher is a function that takes a character as it's argument and returns whether or lamnda not that character is in some set. The class can provide default implementations of common character matchers, such as for whitespace, but the user can define them as required.
  • Extend the character matching to string sequences. This would enable more complex lexical entities, but is starting to blur the line between lexical and syntactic analysis.

Author:
Hamish I A Morgan <hamish.morgan@sussex.ac.uk>

public final void value(StringBuilder builder)

debugContext

public final CharSequence debugContext()
                                throws IllegalStateException
Attempt to reconstruct the whole line on which the current lexeme occurs and return it as a CharSequence. This can be used to produce much more helpful error messages. Note that this method is not guaranteed to success, since it will only return whatever data is still available in the character buffer.

Returns:
the full line of the current lexeme if possible
Throws:
IllegalStateException - when any consistency check fails

position

public uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell position()

Calculate the position, in the underlying ByteBuffer, of the currently advanced lexeme. Return a long integer denoting this position. Passing this integer as an argument to seek() will return Lexer to the state it was at when tell was called.

Note that there is some overhead to calling tell, since the remaining decoded character must be re-encoded to determine byte position. Try to call this method as infrequently as possible.

Specified by:
position in interface uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Seekable<uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell>
Returns:
byte offset of the current lexeme.

position

public void position(uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell offset)
              throws IOException

Resets the lexer to start iterating from the given byte offset. If the offset is not at a valid lexical boundary, behavior will be undefined. Correct behavior is only guaranteed when the given offset is a value previously return by a call to position().

Note: After performing a position(uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell), the line and column number may be incorrect. The column number will correct itself after the next new-line, but the line number will always be wrong, unless a seek(0) is performed. After a call to seek the following fields may be inconsistent:

number
will continue from the current value
line
will restart from 0
column
will restart from 0

Specified by:
position in interface uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Seekable<uk.ac.susx.mlcl.lib.io.Tell>
Parameters:
offset - position in the underlying byte buffer to jump to
Throws:
CharacterCodingException
IOException
